segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 12
segments.en: Linked Discourses 12

segments.pli: 2. Āhāravagga
segments.en: 2. Fuel

segments.pli: 18. Timbarukasutta
segments.en: 18. With Timbaruka

segments.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ viharati.
segments.en: At Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: Atha kho timbaruko paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
segments.en: Then the wanderer Timbaruka went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

segments.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho timbaruko paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

segments.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, sayaṅkataṃ sukhadukkhanti?
segments.en: “Well, Master Gotama, are pleasure and pain made by oneself?”

segments.pli: Mā hevaṃ, timbarukāti bhagavā avoca.
segments.en: “Not so, Timbaruka,” said the Buddha.

segments.pli: Kiṃ pana, bho gotama, paraṅkataṃ sukhadukkhanti?
segments.en: “Then are pleasure and pain made by another?”

segments.pli: Mā hevaṃ, timbarukāti bhagavā avoca.
segments.en: “Not so, Timbaruka,” said the Buddha.

segments.pli: Kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca sukhadukkhanti?
segments.en: “Well, are pleasure and pain made by both oneself and another?”

segments.pli: Mā hevaṃ, timbarukāti bhagavā avoca.
segments.en: “Not so, Timbaruka,” said the Buddha.

segments.pli: Kiṃ pana, bho gotama, asayaṅkāraṃ aparaṅkāraṃ adhiccasamuppannaṃ sukhadukkhanti?
segments.en: “Then do pleasure and pain arise by chance, not made by oneself or another?”

segments.pli: Mā hevaṃ, timbarukāti bhagavā avoca.
segments.en: “Not so, Timbaruka,” said the Buddha.

segments.pli: Kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, natthi sukhadukkhanti?
segments.en: “Well, is there no such thing as pleasure and pain?”

segments.pli: Na kho, timbaruka, natthi sukhadukkhaṃ;
segments.en: “It’s not that there’s no such thing as pleasure and pain.

segments.pli: atthi kho, timbaruka, sukhadukkhanti.
segments.en: Pleasure and pain are real.”

segments.pli: Tena hi bhavaṃ gotamo sukhadukkhaṃ na jānāti, na passatīti?
segments.en: “Then Master Gotama doesn’t know nor see pleasure and pain.”

segments.pli: Na khvāhaṃ, timbaruka, sukhadukkhaṃ na jānāmi, na passāmi.
segments.en: “It’s not that I don’t know or see pleasure and pain.

segments.pli: Jānāmi khvāhaṃ, timbaruka, sukhadukkhaṃ;
segments.en: I do know pleasure and pain,

segments.pli: passāmi khvāhaṃ, timbaruka, sukhadukkhan”ti.
segments.en: I do see pleasure and pain.”

segments.pli: “‘Kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, sayaṅkataṃ sukhadukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṃ, timbarukā’ti vadesi.
segments.en: “Master Gotama, when asked these questions, you say ‘not so’.

segments.pli: ‘Kiṃ pana, bho gotama, paraṅkataṃ sukhadukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṃ, timbarukā’ti vadesi.
‘Kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca sukhadukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṃ, timbarukā’ti vadesi.
‘Kiṃ pana, bho gotama, asayaṅkāraṃ aparaṅkāraṃ adhiccasamuppannaṃ sukhadukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṃ, timbarukā’ti vadesi.
‘Kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, natthi sukhadukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘na kho, timbaruka, natthi sukhadukkhaṃ;
segments.en: Yet you say that there is such a thing as pleasure and pain.

segments.pli: atthi kho, timbaruka, sukhadukkhan’ti vadesi.
‘Tena hi bhavaṃ gotamo sukhadukkhaṃ na jānāti, na passatī’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘na khvāhaṃ, timbaruka, sukhadukkhaṃ na jānāmi, na passāmi.
Jānāmi khvāhaṃ, timbaruka, sukhadukkhaṃ;
segments.en: And you say that you do know pleasure and pain,

segments.pli: passāmi khvāhaṃ, timbaruka, sukhadukkhan’ti vadesi.
segments.en: and you do see pleasure and pain.

segments.pli: Ācikkhatu ca me bhavaṃ gotamo sukhadukkhaṃ.
segments.en: Sir, explain pleasure and pain to me!

segments.pli: Desetu ca me bhavaṃ gotamo sukhadukkhan”ti.
segments.en: Teach me about pleasure and pain!”

segments.pli: “‘Sā vedanā, so vedayatī’ti kho, timbaruka, ādito sato ‘sayaṅkataṃ sukhadukkhan’ti evampāhaṃ na vadāmi.
segments.en: “Suppose that the feeling and the one who feels it are the same thing. Then for one who has existed since the beginning, pleasure and pain is made by oneself. I don’t say this.

segments.pli: ‘Aññā vedanā, añño vedayatī’ti kho, timbaruka, vedanābhitunnassa sato ‘paraṅkataṃ sukhadukkhan’ti evampāhaṃ na vadāmi.
segments.en: Suppose that the feeling is one thing and the one who feels it is another. Then for one stricken by feeling, pleasure and pain is made by another. I don’t say this.

segments.pli: Ete te, timbaruka, ubho ante anupagamma majjhena tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti:
segments.en: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:

segments.pli: ‘avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā;
segments.en: ‘Ignorance is a condition for choices.

segments.pli: saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇaṃ … pe …
segments.en: Choices are a condition for consciousness. …

segments.pli: evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti.
segments.en: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

segments.pli: Avijjāya tveva asesavirāganirodhā saṅkhāranirodho;
segments.en: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.

segments.pli: saṅkhāranirodhā viññāṇanirodho … pe …
segments.en: When choices cease, consciousness ceases. …

segments.pli: evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī’”ti.
segments.en: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, timbaruko paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When he said this, the wanderer Timbaruka said to the Buddha,

segments.pli: “abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama … pe …
segments.en: “Excellent, sir! Excellent! …

segments.pli: esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
segments.en: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

segments.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
segments.en: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

segments.pli: Aṭṭhamaṃ.

suttaplex.blurb: A wanderer named Timbaruka approaches the Buddha while he is on alms round and asks whether pleasure and pain are created by oneself, by another, by both, or by chance. Explaining why he rejects all these options, the Buddha asserts that suffering arises due to conditions.
